item.title: Wife convicted in man's 2002 murder: "Like a made-for-TV movie"
item.description: Burned remains were found in a metal locker near a blueberry field in 2002, but the remains were not identified until 2015.

item.title: Enid, Oklahoma voters boot city council member with white nationalist ties
item.description: Voters in the northwest Oklahoma city of Enid ousted a City Council member who has ties to white nationalism, opting instead for a grandmother who's a longtime youth leader at an area church.

item.title: 4/2: CBS Evening News
item.description: Severe storms cut path through Ohio Valley; New York cafe hires and trains people with autism

item.title: New sonar images show sunken remains of Baltimore's Key Bridge
item.description: Crews in Baltimore opened a second, temporary channel Tuesday to help with wreckage removal and allow small boats to bypass the Francis Scott Key Bridge collapse site. CBS News senior transportation correspondent Kris Van Cleave has the details.

item.title: Tesla stock falls 5% as quarterly sales drop
item.description: Tesla has reclaimed the title of largest electric vehicle seller in the world, so why did its stock fall 5% on Tuesday? Rebecca Elliott, reporter for The Wall Street Journal, joins CBS News to discuss.

item.title: Snapchat friend-ranking feature sparks mental health concerns
item.description: A new friend-ranking feature on the popular app Snapchat is alarming teens and parents. Judy Ho, clinical and forensic neuropsychologist, joins CBS News to discuss.

item.title: Bridge cleanup continues as temporary channels open
item.description: The race to clear the debris from the Francis Scott Key Bridge and reopen the Port of Baltimore continues, as two emergency channels have been opened to allow smaller ships to enter. Local businesses that relied on the nearby port workers, meanwhile, are feeling the effects too. Kris Van Cleave reports.

item.title: Severe storms cut path through Ohio Valley
item.description: Dangerous storms caused high winds, flooding and possible tornadoes across the Ohio Valley on Tuesday. That same system brought a tornado to Oklahoma Monday night. Justin Michaels and Omar Villafranca report.

item.title: How bird flu could affect U.S. dairy supply
item.description: Texas officials are warning dairy producers to take extra precautions after bird flu was detected in cows. At least one dairy worker has also been infected. Amelia Mugavero looks at how this could impact dairy production and what the dangers are for people.

item.title: Trump continues using controversial "bloodbath" language on campaign trail
item.description: Former President Trump is again using the term "bloodbath" on the campaign trail, this time in an attempt to criticize President Biden's immigration policies. Mr. Biden, meanwhile, is launching an ad campaign focused on abortion rights. Nancy Cordes reports.

item.title: New video raises questions about police killing of 15-year-old girl in 2022
item.description: Newly released video of a 2022 police shooting in California showed a 15-year-old girl attempting to surrender before she was killed during a shootout on the side of a highway. Elise Preston reports.

item.title: New York cafe hires and trains people with autism
item.description: Cafe Joyeux in New York City is on a mission to hire and train people with autism, many of whom often have trouble getting jobs. Nikki Battiste has the story.

item.title: Special counsel pushes back at judge in Trump classified documents case
item.description: Judge Aileen Cannon asked special counsel and Trump to file hypothetical jury instructions in the classified documents case by Tuesday.

item.title: 7 aid workers from World Central Kitchen killed in Israeli airstrike
item.description: At least seven aid workers, including one with dual U.S.-Canadian citizenship, with chef José Andrés' World Central Kitchen were killed by an Israeli airstrike in Gaza. Holly Williams has the latest on the U.S. and Israel's response.

item.title: Severe weather to move through more of U.S.
item.description: The dangerous storms in the Ohio Valley will continue moving through the U.S. The Weather Channel meteorologist Alex Wilson has the forecast.

item.title: "CBS Evening News" headlines for Tuesday, April 2, 2024
item.description: Here's a look at the top stories making headlines on the "CBS Evening News with Norah O'Donnell."

item.title: 4/2: Prime Time with John Dickerson
item.description: John Dickerson reports on an Israeli strike on aid workers in Gaza, the state of the EV market after Tesla sales drop, and how new social media features are sparking anxiety among teens.

item.title: Lauren Boebert hospitalized, underwent surgery for blood clot Monday, campaign says
item.description: Rep. Lauren Boebert was taken to a hospital in Loveland after experiencing severe swelling in one of her legs on Monday, her campaign team said. Doctors found a blood clot and the congresswoman was diagnosed with May-Thurner Syndrome.

item.title: CSX adds freight route to transport cargo to New York with Port of Baltimore closed
item.description: CSX has added a freight route to transport cargo to New York while the Port of Baltimore remains closed to larger ships.

item.title: Second temporary passage clears way for more smaller vessels past Key Bridge collapse site
item.description: A second temporary passage was cleared Tuesday for commercial and essential ships in the Patapsco River following the collapse of the Key Bridge in Baltimore.

item.title: What we know about the Israeli airstrike that killed 7 aid workers
item.description: World leaders are condemning an Israeli airstrike in Gaza that killed at least seven aid workers from the World Central Kitchen. The IDF says the strike should not have happened and that it was a "mistake that followed a misidentification." Jonathan Panikoff, director of the Scowcroft Middle East Security Initiative at the Atlantic Council, joins CBS News to assess the state of Israel's operations in Gaza.

item.title: Federal government moves to end nonconsensual pelvic exams by students
item.description: Hospitals must now receive informed patient consent for breast, pelvic, prostate and rectal exams performed by medical students -- particularly on anesthetized patients, the Department of Health and Human Services announced Monday. Michelle Mello, professor of law and health policy at Stanford University, joins CBS News to unpack the new policy.

item.title: Kentucky declares state of emergency as storms pummel area
item.description: A massive storm system is leaving behind a trail of damage as it moves through parts of the Midwest and Northeast. Justin Michaels from The Weather Channel has the latest.

item.title: Woman held captive for months escapes at a Walgreens, police say
item.description: A woman who said she had been held captive by man for months was able to escape during a stop at a Walgreens in Tampa, police said.

item.title: Powerful earthquake hits Taiwan, killing at least 9 people
item.description: Taiwan's strongest earthquake in 25 years hit during morning rush, killing several, injuring hundreds and sparking tsunami warnings as far away as Japan and the Philippines.

item.title: Largest U.S. egg producer finds bird flu in Texas, Michigan plants
item.description: The company said there is no known bird flu risk associated with eggs that are currently on the market and no eggs have been recalled.

item.title: Lizzo says she's not leaving music industry, clarifies "I QUIT" statement
item.description: Lizzo worried fans recently with a statement saying she quit. The singer explained Tuesday what she really meant.

item.title: LG WashCombo review: A washer and a dryer in one, but Is it worth it?
item.description: Check out our full review of the new LG WashCombo 5 cu. ft. ventless washer/dryer appliance.

item.title: Justin Combs' mother speaks out after Diddy's L.A. home raid
item.description: Misa Hylton shared a video and a statement criticizing the "militarized force used" during last week's law enforcement raid of Sean "Diddy" Combs' Los Angeles mansion.

item.title: The 5 best digital notepads in 2024 will free you from paper clutter forever
item.description: Handwrite directly on a display and keep all of your ideas, lists and notes organized with a digital notepad.
